results_summary: The study examined chlorella's impact on performance metrics, but the abstract does not specify the outcomes, leaving efficacy unclear without full results.
population_specificity: Fourteen male trained cyclists.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effects of Chlorella vulgaris supplementation on lipid profiles (TG, TC, LDL-C, HDL-C) in adults.
results_summary: Chlorella vulgaris supplementation significantly reduced TC and LDL-C levels but had no significant effect on TG and HDL-C. The LDL-C reduction was effective at dosages up to 1500 mg/d but not at higher amounts.
population_specificity: 539 adults (264 in the Chlorella group, 275 in the control group) across 10 RCTs.
effective_dosage: Effective LDL-C reduction at dosages between zero and 1500 mg/d.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Chlorella supplementation on glycemic control, lipid profile, and anthropometric indices in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in glycemic control, lipid profile, or anthropometric measurements after 8 weeks of Chlorella supplementation at 1500 mg/day. The researchers concluded that Chlorella at this dosage and duration does not improve these outcomes in T2DM patients.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential role of microalgae, including Chlorella, as functional foods for human oral health, focusing on their anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, antimicrobial, and disease-preventive properties.
results_summary: The study found that microalgae, including Chlorella, exhibit significant anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, antimicrobial, and disease-preventive effects, with potential applications in oral cancer prevention and treatment of chronic periodontitis and microbial oral diseases. However, more research is needed to identify optimal strains and ensure safe, effective products.
population_specificity: General human population (not specified further)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy of Chlorella supplementation on cardiovascular risk factors through a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Chlorella supplementation significantly reduced total cholesterol, LDL-C, systolic and diastolic blood pressure, and fasting blood glucose, but had no significant effect on triglycerides, HDL-C, or BMI.
population_specificity: Subjects with varying health statuses (797 participants across 19 RCTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify dietary supplements, including Chlorella, associated with kidney toxicity based on PubMed case reports.
results_summary: Chlorella was listed among dietary supplements linked to kidney injury in case reports, but no specific details on frequency or severity were provided. The abstract notes that most dietary supplements had only one to three publications over 50+ years.
population_specificity: Not specified (case reports from PubMed, 1966–2016)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Chlorella supplementation on the severity of menstrual pain and systemic symptoms in young women with primary dysmenorrhea.
results_summary: Chlorella supplementation significantly reduced menstrual pain severity, duration, and systemic symptoms (fatigue, headache, nausea, etc.), while also lowering serum levels of prostaglandins, inflammatory markers (hs-CRP), and oxidative markers (MDA). No significant changes were observed in menstrual characteristics, anthropometric indices, or dietary intake.
population_specificity: Young women with primary dysmenorrhea (n=44).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the effects of Chlorella vulgaris supplementation on glucose homeostasis, insulin resistance, and inflammatory biomarkers in patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: Chlorella supplementation significantly reduced weight, liver enzymes, fasting serum glucose, and hs-CRP, while increasing serum insulin and HOMA score in NAFLD patients. The effects on serum glucose and TNF-α levels remained significant even after adjustments.
population_specificity: Seventy NAFLD patients confirmed by ultra-sonographic findings.
effective_dosage: Four 300 mg tablets of C. vulgaris daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the health benefits of Chlorella supplementation and the molecular mechanisms underlying these effects.
results_summary: The study found that Chlorella vulgaris supplementation may help ameliorate hyperlipidemia and hyperglycemia, protect against oxidative stress, cancer, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, due to its unique composition of functional nutrients. Clinical trials supported these benefits.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human health context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the ability of Chlorella vulgaris to detoxify carcinogenic heterocyclic amines (HCAs) in Korean young adults.
results_summary: Chlorella supplementation showed marginally significant effects in reducing urinary MeIQx levels but did not significantly alter PhIP or IQx-8-COOH levels. The study suggests Chlorella may interfere with HCA absorption or metabolism.
population_specificity: 6 Korean females, aged 27.17±7.73 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Chlorella vulgaris induces epigenetic modulation and aids in detoxification against polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs).
results_summary: Chlorella reduced global hypermethylation (5-methylcytosine) compared to placebo and lowered urinary 1-hydroxypyrene (1-OHP) levels, suggesting PAH-detoxification through epigenetic modulation and interference with PAH absorption, distribution, metabolism, or excretion (ADME). However, no changes were observed in DNA methylation at DNMT1 or NQO1.
population_specificity: 12 healthy females
effective_dosage: 4 tablets (≈8.3mg chlorophyll/tablet) three times daily before meals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the immune-stimulating effects of Chlorella and its potential association with autoimmune disease flares.
results_summary: The abstract suggests Chlorella activates immune cells via cytokines and chemokines, but case reports link it to flares in autoimmune conditions like lupus and dermatomyositis. No direct efficacy for dermatologic conditions was demonstrated.
population_specificity: Dermatology patients, particularly those with autoimmune conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Chlorella vulgaris supplementation could improve antioxidant status and reduce oxidative stress in chronic cigarette smokers.
results_summary: Six-week supplementation with Chlorella vulgaris significantly increased serum antioxidant measures and reduced malonedialdehyde (MDA) levels, indicating reduced lipid peroxidation. The effects were consistent across genders, except for vitamin E changes, which were more pronounced in males.
population_specificity: Iranian smokers (mean age 37.11 ± 1.69 years, 18.4% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a Chlorella-derived supplement could prevent the reduction in salivary SIgA secretion rates during intensive kendo training camps.
results_summary: The study found that the Chlorella supplement prevented the decrease in salivary SIgA secretion rates observed in the placebo group during the training camps, suggesting it may help maintain immune function under physical stress.
population_specificity: Ten female kendo athletes participating in inter-university training camps.
study_duration: Tablets were taken starting 4 weeks before the camp until post-camp saliva sampling (total duration varied by camp length: 6-day spring and 4-day summer camps).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effectiveness of Chlorella vulgaris extract (CVE) as an adjunct to standard antidepressant therapy in patients with major depressive disorder (MDD).
results_summary: The study found that CVE significantly improved physical and cognitive symptoms of depression and anxiety compared to standard therapy alone, though affective symptoms improved more in the control group. CVE was well tolerated with no serious adverse events reported.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with MDD according to DSM-IV criteria who were already receiving standard antidepressant therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Chlorella supplementation enhances immune and inflammatory responses, specifically NK cell activity and cytokine production, in healthy humans.
results_summary: Chlorella supplementation significantly increased NK cell activity and serum levels of interferon-γ and interleukin-1β, with a trend toward increased interleukin-12. These changes were significantly greater in the Chlorella group compared to placebo, suggesting immunostimulatory effects.
population_specificity: Healthy humans

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Chlorella ingestion increases salivary secretory immunoglobulin A (SIgA) secretion, potentially improving mucosal immune function in humans.
results_summary: The study found that 4-week Chlorella ingestion significantly increased salivary SIgA concentrations and secretion rates compared to baseline, while placebo ingestion showed no effect.
population_specificity: 15 men

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 6 weeks of Chlorella supplementation could protect smokers against oxidative damage by measuring plasma antioxidant levels and lymphocyte DNA damage.
results_summary: Chlorella supplementation increased plasma antioxidant vitamins (vitamin C and alpha-tocopherol) and improved erythrocyte antioxidant enzyme activities. It also reduced lymphocyte DNA damage, though the placebo group also showed a decrease.
population_specificity: 52 smokers aged 20-65 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether Chlorella supplementation could prevent pregnancy anemia and pregnancy-induced hypertension (PIH) in Japanese pregnant women.
results_summary: Chlorella supplementation significantly reduced the proportion of anemic subjects and lowered incidences of proteinuria and edema (signs of PIH) compared to the control group during the second and third trimesters.
population_specificity: Japanese pregnant women (n=70, with 32 in the Chlorella group and 38 in the control group).
study_duration: From 12th-18th week of gestation until delivery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of chlorogenic acid (CGA) on human semen quality, oxidative stress in spermatozoa, and its potential mechanism of action via the Nrf2 pathway.
results_summary: CGA increased rapid progressive sperm motility and reduced oxidative stress markers (F2-IsoPs) in semen. It also reversed oxidative damage and DNA fragmentation induced by H2O2 while upregulating Nrf2 mRNA expression.
population_specificity: Human semen samples and spermatozoa in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chlorogenic acid (CGA), alone or in combination with cilomilast (CILO), could protect against scopolamine-induced cognitive impairment in mice, focusing on neuroprotective and anti-inflammatory effects.
results_summary: CGA, especially when combined with CILO, reversed scopolamine-induced cognitive deficits, reduced neuronal damage and amyloid beta accumulation, and decreased neuroinflammatory markers like TNF-α and NF-κB. The combination also enhanced cAMP-related pathways, improving neuronal plasticity and survival.
population_specificity: Male albino mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Chlorogenic Acid (CGA) could protect against acetaminophen-induced liver injury (AILI) by modulating the AMPK/mTOR/ULK1 autophagy pathway.
results_summary: CGA protected mice and LO2 cells from oxidative stress and liver injury caused by APAP by activating the AMPK/mTOR/ULK1 pathway, promoting autophagy. These effects were reversed by AMPK inhibition, confirming the pathway's role in CGA's protective action.
population_specificity: Mice and LO2 cells (human liver cell line).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effect of Chlorogenic Acid (CGA) on atopic dermatitis (AD) in mice and explore its mechanism of action.
results_summary: Topical application of CGA significantly reduced dermatitis scores, inflammation markers, and skin fibrosis in AD-induced mice. CGA inhibited the PI3K/Akt and NF-κB signaling pathways, suggesting its anti-inflammatory effects via the Akt1/NF-κB pathway.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice with AD induced by 2,4-dinitrochlorobenzene (DNCB).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chlorogenic acid (CGA) could mitigate the toxicity of a glyphosate-based herbicide (GBH) in rats by evaluating biochemical, oxidative stress, and histopathological parameters.
results_summary: CGA dose-dependently improved biochemical and oxidative stress markers (reducing MDA, 8-OHdG, and restoring GSH, SOD, CAT levels) and reversed histopathological damage caused by GBH in rats. The findings suggest CGA is a promising natural agent against glyphosate-induced toxicity.
population_specificity: 42 Wistar rats divided into six groups of seven animals each.
effective_dosage: 12.5, 25, or 50 mg/kg of CGA administered orally.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chlorogenic acid (CA) could inhibit the virulence and transmission of drug resistance in outer membrane vesicles (OMVs) released by carbapenem-resistant Klebsiella pneumoniae (CRKp) under meropenem (MEM) pressure.
results_summary: The study found that CA inhibits macrophage pyroptosis by blocking the interaction between GroEL and LOX-1, reduces the spread of resistance genes by disrupting conjugation, and prevents MEM hydrolysis by inhibiting resistance enzymes in KOMV-MEM. These effects were demonstrated both in vitro and in vivo.
population_specificity: Mice infected with CRKp-derived OMVs (KOMV-MEM) and bacterial cultures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chlorogenic acid could protect against cisplatin-induced intestinal barrier damage and microbiota disruption in mice.
results_summary: Chlorogenic acid reduced inflammatory markers (IL-6, IL-1β, TNF-α), improved intestinal barrier integrity (increased occludin and ZO-1 expression), and reversed cisplatin-induced gut microbiota dysbiosis, particularly when administered as a pretreatment.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and mucosal protective properties of chlorogenic acid in mitigating 5-FU-induced intestinal mucositis in mice.
results_summary: Chlorogenic acid reduced intestinal histopathological damage, lowered proinflammatory mediators and oxidative stress markers, and modulated key signaling pathways (TLR4/NF-κB/MAPK, AMPK/SIRT1, PI3K/AKT) to protect against 5-FU-induced tissue damage.
population_specificity: Mice with 5-FU-induced intestinal mucositis.
effective_dosage: 10 and 20 mg/kg, administered daily via intraperitoneal injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a composite sensor for accurate detection of Chlorogenic Acid (CGA) in complex matrices like plant extracts, coffee, and fruit juices.
results_summary: The study successfully designed a MIPs-CS:ZnS QDs/PDA composite sensor with high selectivity for CGA, demonstrating a linear detection range of 0.02-11 μg/mL and a low detection limit of 8.9 × 10-3 μg/mL. The sensor showed good recovery rates (88.93-98.49%) in real samples without requiring pre-treatment.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on sensor development).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the acute effects of Chlorogenic Acid (CGA) on liver and kidney function in mice.
results_summary: CGA elevated hydrogen peroxide levels in the liver and kidneys, impaired liver function parameters, and variably affected potassium ion concentration in the kidneys, with more pronounced effects at higher doses (≥240 mg/kg). Histological findings supported these biochemical perturbations.
population_specificity: Swiss mice (n=48, weight-matched into 8 groups of 6).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of chlorogenic acid, alone and combined with endurance training, on oxidative and nitrosative stress indicators in skeletal muscle tissue of pre-diabetic mice.
results_summary: Chlorogenic acid significantly decreased glutathione peroxidase and increased total antioxidant capacity. Combined with endurance training, it showed potential to improve antioxidant capacity and reduce diabetes-related complications.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6 mice fed a high-fat diet to induce pre-diabetes.
effective_dosage: 110 mg/kg body weight, administered three times a week via gavage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chlorogenic acid (CGA) enhances beta-lapachone (β-Lap)-induced cancer cell death by inhibiting autophagy, potentially overcoming drug resistance.
results_summary: CGA significantly enhanced β-Lap-induced apoptosis in cancer cells by activating PKA, which suppressed autophagy via LC3 phosphorylation. This combination was particularly effective in NQO1-overexpressing breast and lung cancers.
population_specificity: Cancer cells (specifically NQO1-overexpressing breast and lung cancer cells)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects and mechanisms of Chlorogenic Acid (CGA) on PTSD-like behaviors using network pharmacology, molecular docking, and experimental validation.
results_summary: CGA alleviated PTSD-like behaviors, improved hippocampal damage, and enhanced synaptic plasticity through antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects by regulating Nrf2 and NF-κB pathways.
population_specificity: Not specified (animal model implied by "vivo experiments").

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Chlorogenic Acid (Cga) could mitigate pyrrolizidine alkaloid (PA)-induced liver damage by influencing the SIRT1/FXR signaling pathway.
results_summary: Cga enhanced SIRT1 activation and FXR signaling, improving bile acid balance in PA-induced liver injury. The protective effects of Cga were significantly reduced when SIRT1 inhibitors were used or in Fxr-KO mice, highlighting the role of the SIRT1/FXR axis.
population_specificity: Murine model (mice)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Chlorogenic Acid (CGA) could protect the pancreas from severe injury in severe acute pancreatitis (SAP) by reducing inflammation and mitigating pathological damage.
results_summary: CGA significantly reduced serum amylase and lipase levels, decreased pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, IL-6, TNF-α), and alleviated pancreatic tissue damage in SAP rats by inhibiting NF-κB and NLRP3 inflammasome activation and activating the Nrf2/HO-1 pathway. Similar anti-inflammatory effects were observed in AR42J cells.
population_specificity: Rats with severe acute pancreatitis (SAP) and AR42J cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of chlorogenic acid (CHA) in treating Alzheimer's disease (AD) when delivered via bifunctional nanomicelles (CI@SPK) designed to enhance bioavailability and target AD lesions.
results_summary: The study found that CHA, when encapsulated in nanomicelles, effectively scavenged reactive oxygen species (ROS), inhibited β-amyloid (Aβ) aggregation, and modulated microglia phenotype from M1 to M2, promoting Aβ phagocytosis and clearance. In vivo results showed improved learning and cognitive function in APP/PS1 mice, with reduced Aβ plaque and inflammation.
population_specificity: APP/PS1 mice (a model for Alzheimer's disease)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the inhibitory mechanism of chlorogenic acid-grafted chitosan (CA-g-CS) against Pseudomonas fluorescens at the gene level, focusing on iron transport and membrane integrity.
results_summary: CA-g-CS treatment significantly down-regulated genes related to iron transport in P. fluorescens, caused membrane surface collapse, reduced bacterial membrane protein content, and decreased iron uptake and intracellular iron content, ultimately retarding bacterial growth.
population_specificity: Pseudomonas fluorescens (bacterial strain)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Chlorogenic Acid (CGA) regulates innate immunity and its underlying molecular mechanisms, particularly its effects against Gram-negative pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa PA14.
results_summary: CGA increased resistance to P. aeruginosa PA14 in a dose-dependent manner, enhanced innate immunity in Caenorhabditis elegans by reducing bacterial burden, inhibited bacterial proliferation and toxin production, and activated mitochondrial unfolded protein response (UPRmt) via transcription factor ATFS-1. It also protected mice from infection and activated UPRmt independently of known immune pathways.
population_specificity: Caenorhabditis elegans and mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of ultrasound-assisted non-enzymatic covalent binding of chlorogenic acids (3-CQA and 4-CQA) with β-lactoglobulin on protein structure and properties, and their potential as delivery vehicles for curcumin and lycopene.
results_summary: The study found that ultrasound-assisted covalent binding, particularly with 4-CQA and alkali-ultrasound treatment, enhanced protein hydrophilicity and thermal stability while altering protein structure. The covalent complexes successfully delivered curcumin and lycopene with high encapsulation efficiencies (82.81–90.51%) and superior stability compared to other delivery systems.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Chlorogenic Acid (CGA) could effectively manage Olanzapine-induced metabolic syndrome in a rat model, comparing its effects to metformin.
results_summary: CGA mitigated Olanzapine-induced hyperphagia, weight gain, hypertension, liver damage, elevated fasting blood glucose, triglycerides, and leptin levels, while also reversing alterations in hypothalamic protein levels (NPY, POMC, AMPK, and 5-HT2CR). However, it did not affect Olanzapine-induced elevation of adiponectin levels.
population_specificity: Female Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine Chlorogenic Acid's anti-aging activity, specifically its ability to mitigate skin photoaging by reducing inflammatory and aging biomarkers while enhancing antioxidant and extracellular matrix integrity markers.
results_summary: Chlorogenic Acid reduced inflammatory markers (NO, COX-2, IL-6) and down-regulated aging-related genes (MMP-1, CASP-3, CASP-8), while up-regulating antioxidant (GPX-1) and ECM integrity markers (TIMP-1, FGF-2), with the most significant effects observed at 25 µg/mL.
population_specificity: UV-exposed human skin fibroblast cells

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chlorogenic acid (CGA) could protect against chronic unpredictable stress (CUS)-induced diminished ovarian reserve (DOR) by modulating the ovarian renin-angiotensin system (OVRAS) and reducing oxidative stress and apoptosis.
results_summary: CGA improved ovarian function, reduced oxidative stress, and downregulated the ACE-AngII-AT1R axis activity in mice subjected to CUS, suggesting it may alleviate stress-induced DOR.
population_specificity: Female mice subjected to chronic unpredictable stress.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a novel selenium-based chlorogenic acid nanoparticle (CHSe NPs) could effectively disrupt the cyclic synergy between oxidative stress and inflammatory response in acute lung injury (ALI).
results_summary: CHSe NPs demonstrated potent antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects by scavenging ROS, modulating macrophage polarization, and regulating key signaling pathways (MAPK and PI3K-Akt), outperforming dexamethasone in ALI mice models.
population_specificity: ALI mice models

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the regulatory effects of chlorogenic acid (CHA) on the immune microenvironment in glioma and assess its potential for clinical application.
results_summary: CHA slowed tumor growth in model mice, extended survival time, enhanced macrophage antigen-presenting function, activated microglia via the JAK-STAT pathway, and improved antitumor effects. A patient treated with CHA achieved partial remission and survived for 5 years and 6 months without toxic side effects.
population_specificity: Model mice and a single human patient with glioma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic effect of chlorogenic acid on CCl4-induced hepatic fibrosis and explore its potential molecular target via the autophagy pathway.
results_summary: Chlorogenic acid improved liver function, reduced oxidative stress and inflammation, and modulated autophagy markers (increasing LC3 and Beclin-1 while decreasing PI3K, AKT, and mTOR). It also lowered NF-κB expression, suggesting anti-inflammatory effects.
population_specificity: Rats with CCl4-induced liver fibrosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the renoprotective effect of Chlorogenic Acid (CGA) in diabetic nephropathy and elucidate its anti-inflammation mechanisms, particularly focusing on Nrf2 pathway activation and NLRP3 inflammasome inhibition.
results_summary: CGA significantly reduced serum creatinine, blood urea nitrogen, and urinary protein excretion in diabetic rats, activated the Nrf2 pathway, and inhibited NLRP3 inflammasome activation. Nrf2 siRNA transfection nullified CGA's effects, confirming its mechanism of action.
population_specificity: Diabetic rat model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the dynamic in vitro digestion properties and prebiotic activities of lotus seed starch-chlorogenic acid complexes under autoclaving treatment.
results_summary: The study found that chlorogenic acid attached to starch via hydrogen bonding, improving its bioavailability, and the digested complexes stimulated the proliferation of beneficial bacteria (Bifidobacterium and Lacticaseibacillus species) and increased acetic acid production.
population_specificity: In vitro study (no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the biological activities and mechanisms of chlorogenic acid (CGA) in treating septic acute liver injury (SALI) using network pharmacology, molecular docking, and in vivo studies.
results_summary: Chlorogenic acid showed significant anti-inflammatory effects and improved liver pathology and apoptosis in a SALI mouse model, likely through the TLR4/NF-κB pathway. Molecular docking confirmed strong binding activity between CGA and core targets related to SALI.
population_specificity: SALI mouse model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chlorogenic acid (CGA) could inhibit UVA-induced cellular senescence in human dermal fibroblasts and prevent skin photoaging in a mouse model.
results_summary: CGA significantly inhibited UVA-induced senescence in human dermal fibroblasts by targeting Enolase 1 (ENO1) and blocking the glycolytic pathway. In a photoaging mouse model, CGA reduced skin wrinkles, alleviated pathological features, and inhibited senescence-associated secretory phenotype (SASP) secretion.
population_specificity: Human dermal fibroblasts (HDF cells) and a photoaging mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory effects of Chlorogenic Acid (CGA) in RAW264.7 macrophage cells and its therapeutic potential for allergic rhinitis (AR) in mice, focusing on the TLR4/MAPK/NF-κB pathway.
results_summary: CGA significantly reduced inflammation markers (NO, TNF-α, IL-6) and suppressed TLR4/MAPK/NF-κB pathway activity in vitro and in AR mice, demonstrating anti-inflammatory effects. Tlr4 overexpression counteracted CGA's benefits, while its inhibition enhanced them.
population_specificity: RAW264.7 macrophage cells and ovalbumin-induced allergic rhinitis mice.
effective_dosage: Varying concentrations (specific amounts not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chlorogenic acid (CGA), when co-delivered with Rhein (RH) via nanoparticles, could synergistically treat ulcerative colitis through anti-inflammatory and antioxidant mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that CP@CGA-FA/TA@RH NPs effectively inhibited the TLR4/MyD88/NF-κB inflammatory pathway and activated the Nrf2/HO-1 antioxidant pathway, demonstrating a significant co-medication effect between RH and CGA for UC treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely preclinical or in vitro/in vivo models, given the nanoparticle development focus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop enteric-coated mucoadhesive beads of Chlorogenic Acid (CGA) for targeted colon delivery to treat ulcerative colitis (UC).
results_summary: The optimized CGA-F2 formulation demonstrated high mucoadhesive efficiency (94.33%), sustained drug release (95.07% over 24 hours), and compatibility with polymers, suggesting promise for UC treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the bactericidal activity of Chlorogenic Acid (CGA) combined with ultraviolet-A light (UVA) against Escherichia coli DH5α, focusing on its potential for food preservation and healthcare applications.
results_summary: CGA + UVA treatment significantly reduced bacterial survival, particularly at acidic pH, and disrupted bacterial cell membranes, DNA, and enzyme activity, including reducing β-lactamase activity and plasmid transforming efficacy. The treatment was also effective in acidic food products like green plum juice.
population_specificity: Escherichia coli DH5α (bacterial strain)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of chlorogenic acid (CGA) on laying performance, antioxidant capacity, egg quality, hepatic inflammation, mitochondrial function, and lipid metabolism in hens under oxidative stress induced by hydrogen peroxide (H2O2).
results_summary: CGA at 600 and 800 mg/kg significantly improved egg production rate, egg quality, and reduced lipid peroxidation compared to the control group. It also mitigated oxidative stress, liver inflammation, mitochondrial dysfunction, and lipid accumulation caused by H2O2, with 800 mg/kg showing greater efficacy.
population_specificity: 360 healthy 43-week-old Hy-Line brown hens.
effective_dosage: 600 mg/kg and 800 mg/kg CGA in the diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the synergistic antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects of chlorogenic acid (CA) combined with Lycium barbarum polysaccharide (LBP) in LPS-induced inflammation in rat alveolar macrophages.
results_summary: The study found that CA and LBP combinations exhibited synergistic antioxidant properties, with the highest activity at a 1:7 ratio. The CA-LBP complex reduced LPS-induced nitric oxide, reactive oxygen species, and inflammatory factors like TNF-α and IL-6.
population_specificity: Rat alveolar macrophages (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: Not specified (ratios tested: CA:LBP = 1:7, among others).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the molecular targets and anticancer mechanisms of Chlorogenic Acid (CGA) and validate its efficacy in inhibiting tumor growth.
results_summary: The study discovered that mitochondrial acetyl-CoA acetyltransferase 1 (ACAT1) is a primary target of CGA, and demonstrated that CGA inhibits cancer cell proliferation by blocking ACAT1 phosphorylation at Y407, both in vitro and in vivo. The findings highlight CGA's potential as a novel anticancer agent.
population_specificity: Preclinical models and phase II clinical trial patients with glioma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate chlorogenic acid's molecular mechanism and potential targets for treating oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC).
results_summary: Chlorogenic acid targeted 23 OSCC-related proteins, with strong binding affinity to MMP9, and downregulation of core targets correlated with improved survival. Enrichment analysis highlighted the importance of MAPK-ERK and MAPK-JNK signaling pathways in its efficacy.
population_specificity: Oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) patients (in silico and survival analysis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether chlorogenic acid (CGA) could prevent urogenital damage caused by particulate matter exposure in rats by enhancing antioxidant defenses and modulating oxidative stress pathways.
results_summary: CGA improved urogenital biomarkers and histopathology structures by enhancing antioxidant enzymes and modulating the OXR1 signaling pathway, counteracting the oxidative stress and kidney dysfunction induced by particulate matter exposure.
population_specificity: Wistar rats exposed to particulate matter.
effective_dosage: 100, 200, and 400 mg/kg, administered via gavage 3 days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate chlorogenic acid's effectiveness as a disinfectant for alginate dental impressions and its impact on physical properties and dimensional accuracy.
results_summary: Chlorogenic acid demonstrated significant antimicrobial effects against common oral pathogens without compromising the physical properties or dimensional accuracy of alginate impressions. All tested concentrations met ISO standards for key properties, though only the 10 mg/mL concentration met the Japanese standard for initial setting time.
population_specificity: Alginate dental impression materials (in vitro study, no human subjects).
effective_dosage: Mixed concentrations: 10 mg/mL, 15 mg/mL, 20 mg/mL; sprayed concentrations: 50 mg/mL, 55 mg/mL, 60 mg/mL.
study_duration: Five-minute incubation period, with disinfection effects assessed at 10, 20, and 30 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Chlorogenic Acid (CGA) could protect against reproductive damage induced by cyclophosphamide (CP) in mice.
results_summary: CGA increased serum testosterone, luteinizing hormone, and follicle-stimulating hormone activity, improved oxidative stress markers, restored testicular morphology, and enhanced steroid regulatory factors and synthase levels, suggesting protective effects against CP-induced reproductive damage.
population_specificity: Male mice treated with cyclophosphamide.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review advancements in nanotechnology for improving the delivery and efficacy of Chlorogenic Acid (CGA) as a medicinal agent or food supplement.
results_summary: The study found that CGA-loaded nanomaterials enhance its bioavailability, stability, and targeted distribution, improving its therapeutic effects and extending food shelf life in nano-packaging.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing research).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the inhibitory effects of Chlorogenic Acid (CGA) on tongue cancer using patient-derived xenograft (PDX) models and hydrogel-embedded drug sensitivity tests (HDST), while also investigating the underlying molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: CGA demonstrated robust inhibition of tongue cancer in both in vivo and ex vivo models, downregulating CD31 and Ki-67 expression, promoting apoptosis, and involving the EGFR-AKT-MMP9 signaling cascade. The study highlights CGA's potential as a therapeutic agent due to its ability to disrupt angiogenesis, suppress proliferation, and induce apoptosis.
population_specificity: Patient-derived xenograft (PDX) models of tongue cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the medicinal value of chlorogenic acid compounds (CGAs) from sweetpotato leaves and their potential as a novel therapeutic strategy for treating idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP).
results_summary: CGAs promoted megakaryocyte differentiation and platelet formation in a murine ITP model, activating the PI3K/AKT signaling pathway. The study demonstrated CGAs' potential to enhance platelet production through this mechanism.
population_specificity: Murine model of ITP (antiplatelet antibody-induced).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the pharmacological impact and underlying mechanisms of Chlorogenic Acid (CGA) in treating idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF).
results_summary: CGA demonstrated antifibrotic effects by modulating key genes (EGFR, MMP9, AKT1, BCL2, IL1B) and pathways, reducing pulmonary fibrosis in a bleomycin-induced mouse model. Network pharmacology and molecular docking identified multiple targets, supporting CGA's multi-target therapeutic potential for IPF.
population_specificity: Murine model (mice) with bleomycin-induced lung fibrosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate folic acid-TPGS-modified chlorogenic acid liposomes (FTCLP) for improved stability, bioavailability, and anti-inflammatory effects in colitis.
results_summary: FTCLP demonstrated high encapsulation efficiency (84.85%) and sustained-release properties, significantly reducing pro-inflammatory cytokines (INF-γ, IL-1β, IL-6, TNF-α, NF-κB) and improving colitis symptoms in a DSS-induced model. It also modulated gut microbiota by increasing beneficial bacteria (Lactobacillaceae, Peptostreptococcaceae) and reducing harmful ones (Bacteroidaceae, Rikenellaceae, Helicobacteraceae).
population_specificity: DSS-induced colitis model (animal study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of chlorogenic acid on the multi-scale structure and digestive properties of lotus seed starch under autoclaving treatment.
results_summary: Chlorogenic acid promoted the formation of a loose gel structure in lotus seed starch, reduced its ordered structure, and increased the proportion of resistant starch from 58.25% to 63.85%. It also decreased thermal stability and viscoelasticity of the starch-chlorogenic acid complexes.
population_specificity: Lotus seed starch (in vitro study, no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve the bioavailability and stability of chlorogenic acid (CA) by developing chlorogenic acid nanoparticles (CA NPs) for targeted therapy in ulcerative colitis (UC).
results_summary: CA NPs demonstrated enhanced cellular uptake, prolonged retention in inflamed colonic tissues, and significant benefits in UC mice, including reduced weight loss, improved colon length, lower disease activity index (DAI), and reduced oxidative stress and inflammation.
population_specificity: DSS-induced UC mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic effects of Chlorogenic Acid (CGA) on kidney fibrosis and its underlying mechanisms, focusing on the TLR4/NF-қB signaling pathway.
results_summary: CGA significantly reduced kidney injury, inflammation, oxidative stress, and fibrosis in UUO models. It also inhibited inflammatory factors and oxidative stress in both in vivo and in vitro models, primarily by modulating the TLR4/NF-қB pathway.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice and HK-2 cells (human kidney proximal tubular cell line).
effective_dosage: 40 and 80 mg/kg/d in mice; 50 and 100 μM in HK-2 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chlorogenic acid (CGA) could provide neuroprotective effects against pentylenetetrazole (PTZ)-induced acute epileptic seizures in mice.
results_summary: CGA pre-treatment significantly reversed behavioral changes, improved neurotransmitter levels, enhanced antioxidant defenses, reduced neuroinflammation, and counteracted hippocampal apoptosis in epileptic mice. The results suggest CGA mediates neuroprotection via modulation of oxidative damage, inflammation, and apoptosis.
population_specificity: Mice with PTZ-induced acute epileptic seizures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of chlorogenic acid (ChA) in maintaining tomato fruit quality and mitigating chilling injury symptoms during cold storage.
results_summary: ChA treatments (10, 50, and 100 mg L-1) delayed weight loss, maintained firmness, reduced oxidative damage (lower MDA and EL), and preserved phenolic content, with optimal results at 50 mg L-1. Higher concentrations did not significantly improve quality further.
population_specificity: Tomato fruit (Solanum lycopersicum L.)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chlorogenic acid (CGA) could protect against sodium nitrite-induced toxicity in the submandibular salivary glands and livers of rats.
results_summary: CGA treatment restored normal histological features, increased superoxide dismutase (SOD) levels, and reduced malondialdehyde (MDA) levels in both salivary glands and livers, indicating antioxidative and anti-inflammatory effects.
population_specificity: Male Sprague Dawley Albino rats (5-6 weeks old, 100-150 g).
effective_dosage: 50 mg/mL CGA every other day, administered orally.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how high-intensity ultrasound (HIU) treatment affects the physiochemical, conformational, and immunomodulatory properties of the OVT-CA complex, focusing on the structure-function relationship.
results_summary: HIU treatment improved the binding efficiency between OVT and CA, reduced particle size, enhanced dispersion, and increased immunomodulatory activity by altering structural properties like surface hydrophobicity and secondary structure. Optimal HIU treatment duration (within 30 min) was crucial for activity enhancement, with structural changes closely linked to immunomodulatory effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or ex vivo study implied).
effective_dosage: Maximum grafting degree of 45.22 mg/g CA.
study_duration: Interaction time reduced from 2 h to 15 min with HIU treatment.
